author: Rob Maetzig
title: New Zealand has highest car depreciation rate in the world, says study
text:
New Zealand has highest car depreciation rate in the world, says study ROB MAETZIG Last updated 14:36, February 7 2017 
Our cars depreciate more than anywhere else in the world, says a new study. 
New cars sold in New Zealand depreciate more than anywhere else in the world, according to a new study. 
The research says Kiwi cars with an average odometer reading of 56,000km - or 14,000km per year - will have depreciated by 53.67 per cent on their recommended retail prices the year they were sold. 
This is the highest depreciation rate in the world - ahead of the United Kingdom (51.90 per cent), USA (50.82 per cent), and Switzerland (47.73 per cent). 
The top 10 in car devaluation. 
Closest neighbour Australia is in 8th spot with a depreciation rate of 45.34 per cent, while China has the lowest rate of the countries studied, at 29.42 per cent. 
READ MORE: New Zealand new vehicle sales blast off on a 2017 flyer 
These conclusions are reached in a study of prices of second-hand cars around the world, conducted by the Europe-based global online used car dealership Carspring. 
The study used data sourced from hundreds of online outlets, as well as "brick and mortar" retailers across five of the biggest cities in each market studied, including New Zealand. 
The goal of the research was to give the public a view as to how cars lose value in New Zealand versus other countries. 
But the organisation that represents the New Zealand new car industry disputes the figures, saying vehicles are hardly ever sold for their recommended retail prices. Ad Feedback 
"Not only that, but New Zealand also has a strong used import sector, that affects depreciation rates," says Motor Industry Association chief executive David Crawford. 
"So my opinion is you've got to take the study's results with a grain of salt. I'd pitch our depreciation rates somewhere between USA and Australia." 
But if the depreciation rates suggested by the study are true, these are what some of our most popular new vehicles should be worth after four years of average use: 
Toyota Corolla GX hatch: $33,590 RRP, $15,562. 
Kia Sportage LX AWD: $41,990 RRP, $19,453. 
Mazda CX-5 GLX: $39,745 RRP, $18,413. 
Hyundai Tucson 2WD: $42,990 RRP, $19,917. 
Suzuki Swift GLX: $23,990 RRP, $11,114. 
Holden Commodore SV6: $55,990 RRP, $24,940. 
Mitsubishi Outlander XLS AWD: $47,490 RRP, $22,002. 
Nissan Qashqai Ti: $43,990 RRP, $20,380. - Stuff
